newsitem.title: GAMBIA: Gambia elections pushed back to Jan 2 - radio.
newsitem.headline: Gambia elections pushed back to Jan 2 - radio.

text.p: The West African state of Gambia has further postponed parliamentary elections to January 2, the elections commission announced on Friday.
A statement read on state radio said campaigning would take place between December 9 and 31 and "the date of polling will be January 2, 1997".

No reason was given for the second revision of the electoral timetable in a week. A government statement on Tuesday said the poll was being pushed back by a day from the original date of December 11. No reason was given then either.
Yahya Jammeh was sworn in as president on October 18 after a September presidential election designed to return the country to civilian rule.
Jammeh, who toppled civilian independence president Sir Dawda Jawara in July 1994, accusing him of corruption, quit the army to stand.
